children.name: Comparing a Machine Learning Algorithm Implemented in F# and OCaml

children.description: A generic graph library for OCaml.

children.description: A large collection of data structures and algorithms for OCaml.

children.description: OCaml library for combinatorics <https://www.lri.fr/~filliatr/combine/>.

children.name: Batteries Included
children.description: A community-maintained foundation library for your OCaml projects.

children.name: Cmdliner
children.description: Declarative definition of command line interfaces for OCaml.

children.name: Core
children.description: Jane Street Capital's standard library overlay.

children.name: React
children.description: React is an OCaml module for functional reactive programming (FRP). It provides support to program with time varying values: declarative events and signals.

children.name: ctypes
children.description: Library for binding to C libraries using pure OCaml.

children.name: easy-format
children.description: Pretty-printing library for OCaml.

children.name: ocaml-rpc
children.description: Light library to deal with RPCs in OCaml.

children.name: ocaml-containers
children.description: A small standard library extension, string library, and (in "misc") a bunch of random things of lower quality. BSD license.

children.name: Type OCaml – Many things about OCaml
More OCaml: Algorithms, Methods, and Diversions
children.description: In More OCaml John Whitington takes a meandering tour of functional programming with OCaml, introducing various language features and describing some classic algorithms. The book ends with a large worked example dealing with the production of PDF files. There are questions for each chapter together with worked answers and hints.

children.name: How to Think Like a (Functional) Programmer
children.description: by Allen Downey and Nicholas Monje – How to Think Like a Computer Scientist is an introductory programming textbook based on the OCaml language. It is a modified version of Think Python by Allen Downey. It is intended for newcomers to programming and also those who know some programming but want to learn programming in the function-oriented paradigm, or those who simply want to learn OCaml.

children.name: OCaml from the Very Beginning
children.description: by J. Whitington - OCaml from the Very Beginning will appeal both to new programmers, and experienced programmers eager to explore functional languages such as OCaml.

children.name: Pearls of Functional Algorithm Design
children.description: by Richard Bird - It summaries 30 hard algorithm problems in function programming world. Although it is for Haskell, the algorithm problems are very interesting and trying to solve them in OCaml also helps the thinking of functional programming. Partial solutions in OCaml are [here](https://github.com/MassD/pearls).

children.name: Real World OCaml
children.description: by Y. Minsky, A. Madhavapeddy and J. Hickey - Functional programming for the masses.

children.name: Unix System Programming in OCaml
children.description: by X. Leroy and D. Rémy – Introduction to Unix system programming, with an emphasis on communications between processes.

children.name: Using, Understanding, and Unraveling OCaml
children.description: This book describes both the OCaml language and the theoretical grounds behind its powerful type system.

children.name: Purely Functional Data Structures
children.description: This is the first or only book focus on various data structures in FP world. A must-read one.

children.name: Mascot
children.description: Mascot is a style-checker for OCaml sources

children.name: pfff
children.description: pfff is a set of tools and APIs to perform some static analysis, dynamic analysis, code visualizations, code navigations, or style-preserving source-to-source transformations such as refactorings on source code.

children.name: infer
children.description: infer is a static analyzer for Java, C and Objective-C

children.name: cDuce
children.description: cDuce is a modern XML-oriented functional language with innovative features.

children.name: Compcert C Compiler
children.description: It is a C Compiler supporting most of the ISO C90 and C99 / ANSI C  features.

children.name: Eff Programming Language
children.description: Eff is a functional language with handlers of not only exceptions, but also of other computational effects such as state or I/O.

children.name: Neko Programming Language
children.description: Originally the compiler was written in OCaml.

children.name: Mezzo Programming Language
children.description: Mezzo is a programming language in the ML tradition, which places strong emphasis on the control of aliasing and access to mutable memory.

children.name: OCaml-Java
children.description: OCaml to Java bytecode compiler.

children.name: Rhine
children.description: A Lisp on LLVM written in OCaml.

children.name: Rust Programming Language
children.description: Originally written in OCaml before bootstrapping.

children.name: Quick C-- Target Language
children.description: It is now a dead project. [Github Repo](https://github.com/nrnrnr/qc--). [Alternative website](http://www.cs.tufts.edu/~nr/c--/qc--.html).

children.description: A command-line tool to manage Github Issues.

children.description: Better OCaml mode for Sublime Text.

children.description: Easy access to the interface information of installed OCaml libraries for editors like Emacs and Vim.

children.description: Indentation tool for OCaml, to be used from editors like Emacs and Vim.

children.description: solutions are [here](https://github.com/MassD/99).

children.name: OCaml at Exercism
children.description: Exercism is your place to engage in thoughtful conversations about code. Explore simplicity, idiomatic language features, and expressive readable code. [Solutions](https://github.com/exercism/xocaml).

children.name: Coq
children.description: Coq is a formal proof management system. It provides a formal language to write mathematical definitions, executable algorithms and theorems together with an environment for semi-interactive development of machine-checked proofs.

children.name: Why3
children.description: Why3 is a platform for deductive program verification. It provides a rich language for specification and programming, called WhyML, and relies on external theorem provers, both automated and interactive, to discharge verification conditions.

children.name: Alt-Ergo
children.description: Alt-Ergo is an open-source SMT solver dedicated to the proof of mathematical formulas generated in the context of program verification.
